Situation1: Their parents directly open up about a personal struggle and look to them for comfort.
Expectation2: Respond to emails and messages within a reasonable time frame
Situation2: Leadership needs a prompt reply to confirm details for an external partner.
Story: I was sitting at the kitchen table, my laptop open and notifications pinging every few minutes. My stepdad sat across from me, his hands wrapped around a mug, eyes tired. He started talking about how overwhelmed he felt at work, how he worried he wasn’t doing enough for our family. I could see he needed me to listen, to reassure him, to be present. But as he spoke, my phone buzzed again—another email from my manager, marked urgent. Leadership needed my confirmation on a project detail for an external partner, and the deadline was in less than an hour. I felt the pressure mounting from both sides: my stepdad’s vulnerability pulling me to stay, to offer comfort, and my team’s expectation that I’d be responsive and reliable. My heart pounded as I tried to focus on his words, but my mind kept drifting to the blinking cursor on my screen. I wanted to be there for him, to show I cared, but I also knew my colleagues were counting on me. I stared at my stepdad, then at my laptop, feeling completely torn.
